So how do you go about constructing the world's
tallest building?

The Burj Khalifa in Dubai is the world's tallest
building.

At 828 meters tall, its 2.5 times the size
of the Eiffel tower, and the records don't
end there.

It's got the world's longest elevator in terms
of distance to travel, the highest outdoor

observation deck, the most stories in any
building in the world and also the highest
occupied floor.

So how do you go about constructing the world's
tallest building?

Well the two main challenges are dealing with
the high winds and the earthquakes, so engineers

came up with this really clever design of
a buttress core with three wings set at 120

degrees from each other all set around a central
hub that's made of concrete so it acts a little

bit like an axel preventing the building from
twisting and turning.

Now if the wind hits two of the wings, the
third wing actually braces against it and
resists the force.

And if you look at the Burj Khalifa in profile
it's actually got a stepped appearance which
breaks up the wind flow and disrupts it.

Now extreme weather and natural disasters
weren't the only challenges the designers

faced, they also had to work out how to ferry
hundreds and hundreds of people up and down

the building everyday and there are 57 lifts
in the whole building.

A number go straight up to the sky lobby so
residents can peel off and go to their various

apartments, others take visitors up to the
outdoor observation deck in double decker
lifts that move 10 meters a second.

Now in the case of a fire, fortunately every
25 stories or so there are refuges so instead

of having to walk down 163 stories all in
one go, there is actually a place for people
to go to safety.

Constructing the world's tallest building
didn't come cheap.

It reportedly cost 1.5 billion US dollars
to construct.

Give us a thumbs up if you wouldn't mind that
in your back pocket.

Originally the project was going to be called
the Burj Dubai but during the recession they

ran out of a bit of money and they had to
call on the UAE President Mr Khalifa, to come
in and bail them out hence the name Burj Khalifa.

And running and maintaining a skyscraper isn't
cheap either, at peak times 36 megawatts of

electricity are needed which is equivalent
to about 360,000 one hundred watt light bulbs
at any one time.

Then you've got a million litres of water
that are needed every day, 10,000 tonnes of

ice to cool the whole building down, and in
Dubai's hot climate all that condensation

that builds up, all the water is actually
collected and farmed out to water the gardens

which is about 20 Olympic sized swimming pools
worth of water.

Then you've got the cleaning of the building
which is done by automated track mounted robots

which take about four months to go around
the whole building.

So pretty much, by the time they finish, they
start again.

Now, for the time being the Burj Khalifa is
the world's highest building.

But there was talk of a mile high skyscraper
being built at the moment it's just talk,
but you never know so watch this space.
